item.title: Some ideas about inequality
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If there are fewer rich people that own more portion of the wealth whilst the majority of people gets less percentage of the wealth, it means that everybody is producing for those rich people. If you believe that it's wrong to redistribute wealth to some extent, you might reconsider your beliefs. If you think I am talking comunism, please heal whatever wounds comunism has done to you and come back to the conversation. No one is talking about comunism here.

If technology allows to be way more productive why don't we work less? Let's say that at a certain point in time, there is a bussiness that has 10 workers. It's a group of 10 people making enough money for all of the 10. Then they decide to buy a machine/software that helps them do their work twice as fast. If this group was a group of equal coworkers, most likely they might decide to work half the time and enjoy their free time. Now, when this is a company with a boss and 9 employees, is it to be considered normal that the boss decided to fire 5 employees and add their former salary to his? Sure, it's something he can do if he wants, but moraly there can be a limit to this. If the boss knows that those 5 employess will not be able to find any other income source, wouldn't it be inmoral for him to let them starve while there is plenty of wealth for all of them?

This example it'a bit limit and therefore exceptional, but let's go to a different situation. After 5 employees are fired, they need to do something else. But... let's imagine that the first 10 workers were producing for their subsistance. They didn't need to do anything else in order to have food, shelter, clothing and even some comodities. What are the 5 jobless people going to do now that the technical advancement has made possible for the boss to fire them? They don't really need to do anything from a materialistic and survival point of view as there is enough... wait, except they don't have access to it. The boss is keeping it. Therefore they need to go back to survival mode and restart from the bottom. Or they can decide to steal. There is enough so eventually stealing is easier than working from scratch, specially if they have to compete with the already established 5 workers + tech company. Or even killing the boss. Not that these ideas are morally better but as understandable as it would be that the boss wants to have more, it would be understandable that the 5 ex-workers had a feeling of unjustice to be satisfied. They also have time and the power of five man. But let's not get violent. Let's imagine that the 5 ex workers will find a way to start their own activity and thanks to their previous expertise, build a similar company that also has a PC and they are able to cover their needs as before... would it make sense that 10 people is working twice as needed just because of the greed of a single person? If 9 people work double because one is wanting to have more, is it ethical for that one person? Is it not rather stupid for them to allow it? We come back to violence, but to some point, not considering your pairs as pairs is somehow violent. Humanity has never really been agaisnt violence anyway, and that's why I'm more talking about being reasonable and things making sense.

Now, would there be conflict if the technical progress' benefit is shared among the whole comunity? Let's see another case: The boss sees that now that we have a computer, we can work less time and tell the employees to reorganize their times so that they can better enjoy their free time. As there is a potential to free 50% of their previous working time, he tells them to keep doing their former work 50% of the time, save 10% for working time where they will think of new ideas to improve their situation and the left 40% is for them to enjoy life.

With the 50% of work, they maintain their prior stable economical situation, plus are investing a 10% in R&D and instead of feeling injustice, the workers feel belonging and loyalty. The boss didn't win a 500% salary increase but won a 40% free time, happier workers (that translate to more stability in his company) and the potential for further improvements (that can also translate to better future). Even, coming to the topic of inequality, I don't think no one in the company would complain if the boss takes a reasonably bigger part of the benefits, as he is the one who started the enterprise, risked his capital and is the mind behind their own capacity to produce their survival means.

We could picture a situation where the extra effort that the PC releashes is divided like that: workers keep 75% of their work, a part is dedicated to further improvements and the rest goes for the boss. It's still inequal, but it's reasonable and more than that: is humane. No greddy firing. No useless extra work.

Maybe it's time we review our economical models, as they are based on producing more and more. When there is enough, we can't continue in the producing mindset. It simply doesn't make sense. Are we stupid?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Suggested text: Our website address is: https://myblog-1gt63hoo0o.live-website.com.

Comments

Suggested text: When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

Suggested text: If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where your data is sent

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

item.title: Inicio del blog

item.content:encoded:
One Planet Initiative

"The way we think about reality is shaping reality. If you want change, talk to people. Even better: give them opportunitties to see for themselves".

Join the movement

Una serie de recursos

Nuestro amplio conjunto de servicios profesionales atiende a una clientela diversa, desde propietarios de viviendas hasta promotores comerciales.

Aplicación Études Arquitecto

  • Colabora con otros arquitectos.
  • Muestra tus proyectos.
  • Experimenta el mundo de la arquitectura.

Boletín Études

  • Un mundo de artículos que invitan a la reflexión.
  • Casos prácticos que celebran la arquitectura.
  • Acceso exclusivo a ideas de diseño.

"Études nos ha ahorrado miles de horas de trabajo y ha desbloqueado perspectivas que nunca creímos posibles".

Annie Steiner

Director General, Greenprint

item.excerpt:encoded: Muestra las entradas más recientes, así como la página de inicio del sitio o una página personalizada definida en los ajustes de lectura. Si existe, la plantilla de página de inicio sobreescribirá a esta plantilla cuando se muestren las entradas en dicha página de inicio.

item.title: Is this comunism?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
No.

HA fundionado la subida de la nueva web? :D :D

It is very common to react to the idea of redistribution by thinking of comunism. Even more, using many examples where comunism failed in order to reject the idea of redistribution beforehand without fully understanding its nuances or considering the potential benefits of a more equitable distribution of resources.

The comunism I see people reject so often, and rightfully so, is based in the concept that no one owns anything. We all would surrender property to a better knowing entity called government that would manage it for us. This is a system that can work with little children in a family setup but definitely not with adults that are considered equal. So trying to govern like a father is a total misunderstanding of the need (?) of centralized decision taking. We can discuss it's scope in another entry but it definitely doesn't include fathering adults. Specially when is regular humans fathering and deciding for millions of other regular humans.

If we see comunism as an extreme, the other extreme "could be unregulated capitalism, where wealth accumulates with a small elite while the majority faces increasing economic hardship. Both extremes can lead to societal dysfunction and undermine the potential for balanced and sustainable growth." (Chat GPT-4 finished that sentence for me. Happy to see it's also obvious to AI and not just to me.)

It totally hit the point. We are talking about redistribution because we are too close to the opossite extreme of comunism. That's why for some people it sounds like it: it goes in the direction of comunism because that is the way to find balance. Allow me an analogy: let's say I'm in Paris and terrible things happen to me so I decided to move to somewhere next to the atlantic pyrinees where I can find the sea, mountains and a lot of healthy peace. Because Paris is so terrifying to me, I run as fast as I can and when I want to look around I see that I am arriving to Madrid. I need to turn around and head back towards Paris in order to find my ideal destination, but it doesn't mean I am going back there.

Similarly, advocating for redistribution doesn't necessarily mean aiming for communism; it's about moving away from the extreme of inequality and towards a more balanced and equitable point.
